title: History of Present Illness
content: The patient reports right knee pain that began three days ago, characterized by tenderness and difficulty walking. The pain is localized to the medial aspect of the knee and worsens with movement, particularly squatting and pivoting. The patient has a history of a tibial plateau fracture 10 years ago, treated conservatively with a brace. The pain has improved over the past few days. The patient denies recent trauma but notes intermittent pain over the past decade. No prior knee arthroscopy has been performed. The patient is currently managing symptoms with ice and rest. The pain is not severe enough to warrant immediate intervention, and the patient is willing to wait and monitor symptoms. The physician suspects moderate osteoarthritis with possible meniscal involvement, but no acute injury is evident on imaging.
